The Barcelona informal settlement in Gugulethu is strewn with reeking portable chemical toilets after residents stopped cleaners from working in a protest against recruitment policies.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: RTC: Reclaim The City; NU: Ndifuna Ukwazi
NOTES: Activists from Reclaim the City and Ndifuna Ukwazi have occupied two provincial government buildings protest and in the hope of pressuring authorities to develop affordable inner city accommodation in Cape Town: Woodstock
At Rhodes University, protest flared up in the form of a spontaneous march around campus, trailed by police cars
Steenberg residents returned to continue their protest held outside a church in Galilee Street against a proposed erection of a cellphone mast there.
Bhisho Park ratepayers have called on the Buffalo City Metro to pay R2500 in compensation to each household affected by a power outage of eight days. They marched to the metro's offices in Bhisho.
Residents of Eshowe, northern KwaZulu-Natal, went on a service delivery protest. They blockaded the towns busiest street with burning tyres and concrete rubbish bins.

Over three days, Komga has been host to service delivery protests. About 300 protesters gathered in a field close to Happy Valley township after burning tyres and blocking the road with tree stumps to restrict entry to the town.

A protest took place in Pimville, Soweto, against the installation of prepaid electricity meters under control. About 50 Pimville residents had blocked Modjadji Road with burning tyres, forcing Eskom employees to abandon their meter installations for the day.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
NOTES: Officials in the departments health facilities started picketing outside the Polokwane Hospitals entrance, demanding to be paid their bonuses. Trade union Nehawu said the strike would continue until their demands were met.
Students have been blocking entrances, damaging University of Venda property and clashing with police in a renewal of student protests.
Eshowe community members held a destructive protest at the Eshowe constituency offices. The community allegedly burnt tyres near the offices and damaged the windows
An anti-xenophobia march, lead by the African Diaspora Forum (ADF) and consisting of 200 supporters took to the streets of Johannesburg.
Over three days, Komga has been host to service delivery protests. One protester was taken to Frere Hospital after being hit by rubber bullets by police while 8 were arrested.
Three schools were set alight in Marite in Bushbuckridge, Mpumalanga, as the community demanded the tarring of a road in the area.
Four cars were torched in downtown Polokwane in an apparent protest against drugs.

Students have been blocking entrances and damaging University of Venda property and clashing with police. Four student protesters were arrested on charges of public violence and will appear in the Thoyohandou magistrates court.
Police are monitoring the situation in Olievenhoutbosch, Centurion where the R55 has been blocked with rocks and tyres.
In Elsies River, protesters blocked the surrounding streets with burning tyres, furniture and mattresses. Police used rubber bullets, tear gas and stun grenades. Protesters threw rocks.
Police kept a close watch as the protests continued in Eshowe over service delivery.

Over three days, Komga has been host to service delivery protests. About 300 protesters gathered in a field close to Happy Valley township after burning tyres and blocking the road with tree stumps to restrict entry to the town.

A protest was staged on the Jammie Plaza at the University of Cape Town, with students from the Palestine Solidarity Forum (PSF) joining forces with students protesting for the Fees Must Fall (FMF) movement to defend the space together.
Activities at the University of Venda were shut down on as a result of student protests.
Government has appealed for calm in Vuwani after fresh violence erupted following the Municipal Demarcation Board's announcement that it would not review its decision to shift boundaries in the area.
Members of the taxi fraternity, the community policing forum and thousands of other marchers as they moved through the streets of Naturena with placards calling for rapists to be brought to book.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
NOTES: Protesters, supported by NEHAWU, have set tyres alight in the hope of getting their demands met in Newcastle.
A march started at National Treasury offices in Pretoria before heading to the Union Buildings over the recent cabinet reshuffle.

An angry mob tried to burn the structure down in Mitchells Plain. Police opened fire with rubber bullets in a bid to disperse the 300-strong mob outside the suspects home in Matroosberg Street, Tafelsig
Over 200 people protested outside Parliament calling for the immediate resignation of President Jacob Zuma.
Hundreds of people have gathered in Church Square in Pretoria to protest against President Jacob Zuma's Cabinet reshuffle.
Outsourced workers at the embattled Passenger Rail Agency of South Africa (Prasa) staged a protest outside the entity's offices in Hatfield demanding to be hired permanently by the parastatal.
Amid the spreading protests against President Jacob Zuma's reshuffling of the cabinet, a handful of Johannesburg residents picketed outside the Gupta family compound in Saxonwold Johannesburg.
Hundreds of residents from the Tafelsig area of Mitchells Plain turned up at the local magistrate's court to protest, and demand justice following the murder of 11-year-old Stacha Arendz.
Two suspected robbers were burnt to death and two others were injured in Ga-Kgwete near Mecklenburg in Limpopo.
Thousands of protesters have gathered for the anti-Zuma march in Cape Town, stretching from St. Georges Cathedral to the train station.
A gunman, who hid away at a local spaza shop after allegedly shooting and killing a 16-year-old boy, was caught by an angry mob.
Save South Africa supporters camped out at Church Square in Pretoria in protests.
About 400 community members clashed with police outside the Richmond Magistrate's Court. Police retaliated with stun grenades and rubber bullets to disperse the unruly crowd
A school administration block has been burnt just four days after fresh violence erupted in Vuwani over the municipal boundary line.
Thousands of Save South Africa supporters have descended on Church Square in Cape Town to call for President Jacob Zuma to step down.
Thousands have gathered near the Old Durban Drive-in to protest President Jacob Zuma's recent Cabinet reshuffle.
Thousands of Garden Route residents stood in solidarity with the rest of the country, calling for President Jacob Zuma to step down: George
Archbishop Emeritus Desmond Tutu and his wife Leah  joined protesters outside the retirement home they are staying at in Hermanus, to add their support to nationwide anti-Zuma marches.
Police fired rubber bullets and tear gas at ANC supporters outside luthuli house in violent clashes. Several people were injured in the violence.
ANC demonstrators outside Luthuli House in Johannesburg grabbed and attacked one of three people, believed to be DA supporters, who ran into their march with a banner that read: "You must be joking".
Thousands of Garden Route residents stood in solidarity with the rest of the country, calling for President Jacob Zuma to step down: Knysna
Thousands of Garden Route residents stood in solidarity with the rest of the country, calling for President Jacob Zuma to step down: Mossel Bay
A protest against crime in Ocean View turned violent when youths attempted to block roads by burning tyres and throwing stones. Police used teargas and rubber bullets to disperse them.
The Democratic Alliance held pickets in Pietermaritzburg.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
NOTES: After the ANCYL interruted a peaceful march with violence, police intervened, hurling stun grenades at youth league members who went on the rampage, destroying the DA's gazebo and tables before throwing eggs at the demonstrators.
Thousands of Garden Route residents stood in solidarity with the rest of the country, calling for President Jacob Zuma to step down: Plettenberg Bay

Police used rubber bullets and teargas to disperse disgruntled Polokwane residents who blocked roads. Residents had burned tyres and blocked roads, as they joined nationwide action against President Jacob Zuma.

As South Africans came together in a series of protests across the country calling for President Jacob Zuma to step down, the youth in Port Elizabeth made their dissatisfaction with Zuma heard at a peaceful protest rally attended by thousands of residents.

The crowd of an estimated 40 000 people from different political organisations, civil organisations, unions and the general public gathered at the Union Buildings in Pretoria in the first mass protest against a sitting government since the dawn of democracy.
The Democratic Alliance held pickets at major intersection in Rustenburg, as part of the call for President Jacob Zuma to resign as head of the country.
Protest action at the intersection near Somerset West in Cape Town took place with burning tyres and stone throwing by protesters
About 150 people from the Little Karoo town of Barrydale participated in a peaceful anti-Zuma protest on Route 62.
About 300 residents of Mbekweni informal settlement marched to the Paarl Magistrates Court.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: SATAWU: South African Transport and Allied Workers Union; NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
NOTES: Over 150 striking workers march down Klipfontein Road in Rondebosch, Cape Town to demand better wages and working conditions. Unions were represented included SATAWU and NUMSA.
Community members caught a man who had killed a child in Soweto and assaulted him but did not kill him.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: HOSPERSA: Health and Other Service Personnel Trade Union of South Africa
NOTES: The Health and Other Service Personnel Trade Union of South Africa (Hospersa) marched to Northdale Hospital, protesting against a nursing operations manager allegedly being "subjected to religious discrimination".

Thousands of marchers led by the EFF have gathered in Pretoria's Church Square, singing and dancing to shake off the grey clouds above them, as various political parties prepare to march to the Union Buildings to call for President Jacob Zuma to step down.

Four people have been arrested for public violence in Stutterheim following a violent protest allegedly by Amahlathi Local Municipality workers. A municipal building was damaged and roads were blocked with burning tyres
A group of women gathered outside the Hawks offices in Port Elizabeth in support of victims they say had been roped in by "pimps" belonging to the pastors church.

At least 15 people were injured and three houses vandalised in a dispute between members of a local church and residents in Mokhurumela, outside Senwabarana in Limpopo. Church members started hurling stones at the tavern and tavern owner's house.
A group of ten people from Johannesburg Against Injustices (JAI) conducted a protest" outside the Military Museum in Saxonwold, Johannesburg where the Gupta-organised event was being held.
Police are investigating a case of assault after a Democratic Alliance member was attacked, allegedly by ANC members, during an election campaign in Nquthu on Monday.
Pensioners and supporters with the help of Right2Know picketed at Parliament to protest against deductions from their social grants.
The Democratic Alliance took to the streets in Polokwane, Limpopo in a march against President Jacob Zuma.

Six cars were damaged by people throwing stones in Vuwani during protest action. Two people were killed in Vuwani in Limpopo on when the car they were travelling in crashed into a pipe that was being used to barricade a road (during a protest), and burst into flames.
Police officers arresting a teenager caught with drugs in Manenberg came under attack from angry residents, who pelted their vehicles with stones, demanding that the man be released.
Student protesters handed over a memorandum to the University of the Witwatersrand, in which they demanded the removal of the Respublica facilities manager.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
NOTES: Hundreds of Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu) members marched to Absa head office in Johannesburg to hand over a memorandum of demands, calling for the bank to repay bailout money paid to Bankorp by the Reserve Bank during apartheid.
An ANC regional deputy decretary was shot several times and died as he arrived at his home in Emfundweni, ward 13 in Umzimkhulu.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; NTEU: National Tertiary Education Union
NOTES: Both the National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union (Nehawu) and the National Tertiary Education Union (NTEU) joined protests at the Rhodes University in Grahamstown.
Members of the South African Communist Party (SACP) picketed outside the Treasury in Pretoria, calling for an end to the capture of the financial sector.
In Coligny, protesters looted a liquor store and stole cool drinks in service delivery protests.
Klipspruit residents have blocked the renovation of one of the schools in protest, claiming that they were not informed about the project.
A truck was set alight during a service delivery protest in Lichtenburg.
At TUT, security workers embarked on a peaceful protest at the main campus in Pretoria West demanding that management honoured agreements made during previous protests.
Nearly 200 scientists and science lovers took to the streets of Durban in support of science.
About 100 Hangberg residents including school children marched in Hangberg, Hout Bay, demanding better policing and tougher measures against crime and drug-dealing.
Amalinda Forest shack dwellers (in East London) took to the streets in a cry for attention to their housing and electricity needs in their 30-year-old settlement.
A bottle store was looted and pupils removed from schools in Coligny during a protest. Public order police are managing the situation. No reports of injuries have been received
In Lichtenburg, several shops were looted. Three trucks are believed to have been set alight by protesters in ongoing protest violence after the death of a child.
Police were forced to fire rubber bullets and stun grenades to disperse angry crowds in Coligny.
Residents of Fine Town informal settlement in Johannesburg took to the streets demanding they be allocated stands in the nearby Moriting informal settlement. They blocked roads with burning tyres.
Police fired rubber bullets as residents in Lenasia South barricaded roads, burnt tyres and threw rocks, in protest against what they called an illegal land invasion.
Police were forced to fire rubber bullets and stun grenades to disperse angry crowds in Lichtenburg.
The man accused of killing 13-year-old Rene-Tracy Roman from Lavender Hill abandoned his bid for bail after residents protested inside and outside the court (Mitchells Plain).
200 students marched to the Mankweng (Turfloop) police station demanding to be protected from criminals who are terrorising them.
Hundreds of CPUT students living at New Market Junction residence in Woodstock were protesting over a lack of proper facilities, and alleged unlawful evictions.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: PAGAD: People Against Gangsterism and Drugs
NOTES: About 70 Bokmakierie residents (Athlone) and PAGAD members held an unplanned march and picket to protest against gang shootings, drugs and crime in their area.

A Limpopo chief fled his home in Diphale village near Burgersfort after community torched his house and the traditional authority offices. Roads leading to the village were still barricaded with stones and tree trunks.

There was singing and dancing outside the Durban High Court during a protest as the Judge granted an interim order compelling waste management giant EnviroServ to cease all acceptance, treatment and disposal of waste at its Shongweni landfill.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: SACCA: South African Cabin Crew Association
NOTES: South African Cabin Crew Association members picketed outside the offices of South African Airways (kempton Park) over meal allowances.
A small group of protesters blocked the roads into the Ndaleni area just outside the Richmond CBD with concrete slabs, burning tyres and rocks.

SOURCE: The community of Fleurhof on the West Rand took to the streets in protest against lack of electricity. They blocked Main Reef Road with burning tyres and stones, demanding that the electricity be restored.
NOTES: The community of Fleurhof on the West Rand took to the streets in protest against lack of electricity. They blocked Main Reef Road with burning tyres and stones, demanding that the electricity be restored.
Nearly 2,000 learners from schools in the Eastern Cape marched to the provincial education department in Zwelitsha, King Williams Town on Freedom Day. The march was supported by Equal Education.
About 500 people gathered at a stadium following a march from Njoli Square in Port Elizabeth. The marchers were made up of various Civil Society organisations under the campaign of SaveSA.
Outside the Coligny court house, residents of Tlhabologang sang liberation songs and waved placards calling for an accused murderer not to be granted bail.
A pastor was killed on his way to the UN camp in May 2014 in Bentiu town.

Report that at least 20 detainees have died while in government custody in Juba between February 2014 and December 2016. Conditions of detention, including torture and other ill-treatment, inadequate food, absence of clean water and inadequate access to medical care contributed to all of these deaths.
Two pastors from the St Andrews church in Bor were killed in a road ambush laid by unknown gunmen along the Juba-Bor road in February 2015.
Two pastors were killed between Bailiet and Ulang Counties in Upper Nile State by government troops in the context of clashes in the area in May 2015.

Report that at least 20 detainees have died while in government custody in Juba between February 2014 and December 2016. Conditions of detention, including torture and other ill-treatment, inadequate food, absence of clean water and inadequate access to medical care contributed to all of these deaths.
SPLM-N abducted two children from refugee sites in Unity state in 2015.
In July 2015, a pastor was killed by government soldiers based on his ethnicity at Pajut area in Jonglei.
Unknown gunmen shot and killed a priest in Morobo county in November 2015.
In December 2015, three children were killed and maimed in air strikes by the Sudan Armed Forces on Khor Tumbak, Maban county, Unity State, South Sudan.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
NOTES: NSS arrested a journalist in Juba for criticizing in an article SPLM's human rights record. He was held in incommunicado detention at the NSS headquarters in Juba until his release in February. While in detention, he was subjected to torture and other ill-treatment.

ACTOR1: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Maj. Gen. Makuach Teny Yuok, a senior military officer in the armed opposition faction of SPLA-IO, defected from the opposition faction and formed a new rebel group called the National Resistance Movement and Army (NRM/A).
In the course of their redeployment to Digala Boma, Rajaf County in Central Equatoria SPLA reportedly stole lands, looted crops and property and harassed people.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
ALLY_ACTOR_2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: NSS officers halted a Protocol Driver for Riek Machar on his motor vehicle in Juba, confiscating his property, tieding, blindfolding and beating him repeatedly, and threatened to kill him. In another incident, NSS officers fired at a second Protocol vehicle for the FVP after its driver failed to comply with their orders to pull over.
SPLA shot and killed a Sister of the Catholic Diocese of Yei while on medical duty. Despite reports of arrests and investigations, justice had not yet been done as of February 2017.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO soldiers attacked a government forces patrol at the Leer airstrip in Unity. Three SPLA and two IO soldiers were wounded. CTSAMM assessessed that the patrol were in violation of the PCTSA.
Authorities arrested and detained the Ceasefire and Transitional Security Arrangements Monitoring Mechanism (CTSAMM) team leader in Torit.

Report that at least 20 detainees have died while in government custody in Juba between February 2014 and December 2016. Conditions of detention, including torture and other ill-treatment, inadequate food, absence of clean water and inadequate access to medical care contributed to all of these deaths.
Shilluk leaders accused Agwelek commander General Johnson Olony of killing a senior Agwelek officer from a section of the Shilluk tribe in Lelo area of Upper Nile in 2016.
Clashes between government forces and armed groups in Torit in Eastern Equatoria on 9 July following outbreak of violence in Juba. No reported fatality.
Unknown gunmen shot and killed a priest in Amadi.
SPLA forces reportedly executed seven unarmed civilians in Torit.

Fighting in Lafon town on 8 and 15 August between SPLA and armed groups. On 8 August, armed groups reportedly gained control of the town, while on 15 August, SPLA came to retake the area from them. During the violence, reports of mistreatment of civilians by armed groups, forced recruitment by armed groups as well as forced displacement, abductions, sexual violence and heavy looting of nutrition supplies, medicines, schools and houses. The entire population of the town was displaced and as of four months later, only half had returned.
SPLA gang-raped six women in Mayendit county in Unity state.

Fighting in Lafon town on 8 and 15 August between SPLA and armed groups. On 8 August, armed groups reportedly gained control of the town, while on 15 August, SPLA came to retake the area from them. During the violence, reports of mistreatment of civilians by armed groups, forced recruitment by armed groups as well as forced displacement, abductions, sexual violence and heavy looting of nutrition supplies, medicines, schools and houses. The entire population of the town was displaced and as of four months later, only half had returned.

Clashes between Dinka Ngok and Beli communities in Bahr Gel of Lakes state following the creation of new states in the region. No mentioned fatality. The clashes are said to have continued through to January 2017.
Three humanitarian workers were killed in August in South Sudan in unclear circumstances.
Reports of civilians being killed, raped and abducted and of the forced recruitment of children in areas including Guit in Unity in August and September.

Fighting in Lafon town on 8 and 15 August between SPLA and armed groups. On 8 August, armed groups reportedly gained control of the town, while on 15 August, SPLA came to retake the area from them. During the violence, reports of mistreatment of civilians by armed groups, forced recruitment by armed groups as well as forced displacement, abductions, sexual violence and heavy looting of nutrition supplies, medicines, schools and houses. The entire population of the town was displaced and as of four months later, only half had returned.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Heavy clashes between SPLA and SPLA-IO in the Ifuotu mountains area in Eastern Equatoria left 11 SPLA and at least one opposition soldier killed.

ACTOR2: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
NOTES: Unidentified assaillants shot and killed an SSNPS officer at the Juba-Yei road near a UN PoC site.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA launched ground attacks on SPLA-IO positions near Lainya early September, burning down houses and looting properties.
SPLA forces razed the village of Lobonok, leaving unknown amount of fatalities and level of destruction in one of the most severe violence by government troops.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Aerial bombardements by SPLA on SPLA-IO positions near Yei early September.
Four humanitarian workers were killed in September in South Sudan in unclear circumstances.
SPLA abducted approximately 25 women, including at least two children, in Juba in September.
Report of looting and harassment by uniformed people, including cases of rape, in September and October in the Kajo-Keji region.

ACTOR1: SPLA/M-In Opposition-Deng Gai: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition (Deng Gai Faction)
NOTES: Members of the pro-Taban Deng Gai faction of SPLA-IO forces abducted 26 youths to forcefully recruit them into their forces in Thokwathnwyotni, Guit County, in Unity in September. One of them escaped. At least three others were abducted for the same purposes in Guit the same month.
Reports of civilians being killed, raped and abducted and of the forced recruitment of children in areas including Guit in Unity in August and September.

Clashes between cattle keepers allegedly supported by SPLA and youth in Sindiru and Morsak villages in Central Equatoria in September resulted in at least a dozen deaths, 5,000 civilians displaced, homes torched and livestock looted.

Clashes between cattle keepers allegedly supported by SPLA and youth in Sindiru and Morsak villages in Central Equatoria in September resulted in at least a dozen deaths, 5,000 civilians displaced, homes torched and livestock looted.
Five SPLA soldiers allegedly abducted, raped and killed three women going to a local market in Yei county.
SPLA soldiers in civilian clothes reportedly raped three women in Guit county in Unity.
Around 1,000 SPLA soldiers and members of an armed militia reportedly burned and destroyed crops and looted properties in Ding Ding, in Unity.

ACTOR1: Bor Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
ALLY_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-); Unidentified Communal Militia (South Sudan)
ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Clashes bewteen Dinka Bor cattle keepers backed by SPLA and local Youths with SPLA-IO elements in Lobonok between September and October, causing destruction to civilian property and displacement.
Clashes between SPLA and unidentified armed groups between Pajok and Ayaci in Magwi county, Eastern Equatoria, left several people dead.
Report that SPLA looted properties and livestock, raped women and girls, occupied schools and arrested several men on 3 October in Pajok, Ayaci, Palwar and Lerwa in Magwi County, Eastern Equatoria.
Report that SPLA looted properties and livestock, raped women and girls, occupied schools and arrested several men on 3 October in Pajok, Ayaci, Palwar and Lerwa in Magwi County, Eastern Equatoria.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Clashes between SPLA and SPLA-IO in Liang Boma (southern part of Maban County), Upper Nile left two civilians dead and forced 10,000 people to flee to Bunj town.
SPLA allegedly attacked six villages in Unity state on 13-14 October, firing indiscriminately at civilians, pillaging resources and burning down at least 40 houses.

SPLA soldiers allegedly attacked six villages in Matangai payam over 13-14 October, indiscriminately firing at civilians, pillaging their property and burning down at least 40 houses. Unknown number of casualties.
SPLA allegedly attacked six villages in Unity state on 13-14 October, firing indiscriminately at civilians, pillaging resources and burning down at least 40 houses.

SPLA soldiers allegedly attacked six villages in Matangai payam over 13-14 October, indiscriminately firing at civilians, pillaging their property and burning down at least 40 houses. Unknown number of casualties.

Unknown gunmen attack a group of six Sudanese men who had travelled from Ardeba to Shatta Boma in Maban County, Upper Nile. Clashes ensued involving SPLM-N and the host community in Maban, leaving 11 civilians killed, forcing hundreds of people to flee, including from surrounding villages, in fear of further attacks, and leaving villages looted and houses burnt down.

Unknown gunmen attacked a group of six Sudanese men who had travelled from Ardeba to Shatta Boma in Maban County, Upper Nile. Clashes ensued involving SPLM-N and the host community in Maban, leaving 11 civilians killed, forcing hundreds of people to flee, including from surrounding villages, in fear of further attacks, and leaving villages looted and houses burnt down.
Report of looting and harassment by uniformed people, including cases of rape, in September and October in the Kajo-Keji region.
Clashes between Maban community and Sudanese refugees from Blue Nile in Maban in November left at least 12 killed from the host community.
Suspected gunmen from Northern Liech state attacked Dany village in Tuoch county, newly created Ruweng state, in November, leaving one person killed.

NOTES: Series of clashes in December between the SPLA and SPLA-IO in and around Nasser, including south of the Sobat River. Government deployed helicopter gunships and an aircraft to drop bombs south of the Sobat River. No mention of fatality.
Report of armed clashes between unknown groups in Terekaka town in December, forcing aid workers to be relocated.

NOTES: SPLA and SPLA-IO forces led by Deng Gai reportedly attacked SPLA-IO's Machar positions in Koch and Mayendit Counties between 12 and 18 December, which resulted in at least 14 civilians killed and the looting of civilian property.
Unidentified gunmen attacked a vehicle traveling from Juba to Torit at Khordilep, about 24 km from Torit, setting the vehicle on fire and killing 8 of the 11 passengers.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: SPLA/M-In Opposition-Deng Gai: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition (Deng Gai Faction)
ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA and SPLA-IO forces led by Deng Gai reportedly attacked SPLA-IO's Machar positions in Koch and Mayendit Counties between 12 and 18 December, which resulted in at least 14 civilians killed and the looting of civilian property.

On 17 December, one South Sudan National Police Service officer and a child were reportedly killed in an ambush west of Magwi, while a number of SPLA soldiers were reportedly killed in an ambush west of Torit town.

On 17 December, one South Sudan National Police Service officer and a child were reportedly killed in an ambush west of Magwi, while a number of SPLA soldiers were reportedly killed in an ambush west of Torit town.

ACTOR1: SSPPF: South Sudan Peoples Patriotic Front
ACTOR2: SSNLM: South Sudan National Liberation Movement
NOTES: South Sudan Peoples Patriotic Front elements reportedly attacked a military post at Bazungua in Yambio County, killing two government-aligned South Sudan National Liberation Movement soldiers.

NOTES: SPLA and SPLA-IO forces led by Deng Gai reportedly attacked SPLA-IO's Machar positions in Koch and Mayendit Counties between 12 and 18 December, which resulted in at least 14 civilians killed and the looting of civilian property.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
NOTES: NSS arrested six Sudanese refugees working as traders in Maban over allegedly transporting goods without paying taxes. One trader attempted to escape and the security forces reacted, beating him to death. This is believed to have sparked wider clashes in the days that followed.

Sudanese refugees from Blue Nile allegedly killed a local militia leader and burnt down his home in Maban, reacting to the killing of a Sudanese refugee trader by government forces on 22 December. This sparked wider violence in the days that followed between the local and refugee communities.
In an attack in Jonglei on 25 December, armed men shot seven civilians dead and wounded two others in Baping village, Twic East County.

ACTOR1: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO forces detained the government-appointed Panyijar County Commissioner after he landed in Ganyiel. The pro-Machar opposition later claimed that he had defected.

ACTOR1: SSPPF: South Sudan Peoples Patriotic Front
NOTES: Suspected SSPPF members ambushed an SPLA convoy at Rimenze Boma, north-east of Yambio town, leaving 2 SPLA soldiers killed.
15 people were reportedly killed in fighting between Belle youth from Bahr Gel Payam and Gok youth from Cueibet County in Lakes state.
A fisherman was reported killed and another survived after an attack carried out by suspected Murle tribesmen at Ajwara area in Pochalla
gunmen raid a village near Torit and are pushed back by locals.
Local witnesses in Yambio accuse government forces of attacking and killing at least 5 civilians over the New Year period.
five people were killed in separate incidents of cattle raiding in Northern Liech State at the beginning and the middle of the week

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Report of clashes between government and opposition soldiers in several areas of Nasser on 2 January (Ketbek Nordeng, Wecjoak, Kuerengke, Wangbup, Nayguen and Wathmalual) resulting in homes looted and razed, damaged UNMISS property (accomodation containers and an armoured personal carrier) and forced displacement of around 33,000 people. No mention of fatalities.

ACTOR1: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Suspected SPLA-IO forces clashed with SPLA along the Torit-Juba road, west of Torit town, killing three SPLA soldiers and injuring two others. On the same day, suspected SPLA-IO elements also attacked a prison facility along the Torit-Magwi road, south-west of Torit town, leaving six prison guards missing.

At least two people have been killed and six others are wounded after a public bus carrying passengers came under attack some 20 minutes drive from Torit town. Gunmen fire indiscriminately at the bus before retreating into the bush.
Unknown gunmen attacked a vehicle carrying people at Khor Langa area along the Juba-Yei road , resulting in 7 deaths.
SPLA soldiers allegedly detained two civilians in the Yei area, who were later found dead.

ACTOR2: SSPPF: South Sudan Peoples Patriotic Front
SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; OCHA; UN Security Council
NOTES: Clashes between government troops and suspected SSPPF fighters in five villages north of Yambio (Bazumburu, Bazungua, Bodo, Gitikiri and Rimenze). Unspecified number of civilians killed in the fighting (10 spread over 4 locations), as well as houses burned down and property destroyed. At least 7,000 people were displaced from the area.

ACTOR2: SSPPF: South Sudan Peoples Patriotic Front
SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; OCHA; UN Security Council
NOTES: Clashes between government troops and suspected SSPPF fighters in five villages north of Yambio (Bazumburu, Bazungua, Bodo, Gitikiri and Rimenze). Unspecified number of civilians killed in the fighting (10 spread over 4 locations), as well as houses burned down and property destroyed. At least 7,000 people were displaced from the area.
At least 15 people were confirmed killed over a land dispute at Kaljak area which lies on the border between South Sudans Northern Liech and Ruweng States.

ACTOR2: SSPPF: South Sudan Peoples Patriotic Front
SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; OCHA; UN Security Council
NOTES: Clashes between government troops and suspected SSPPF fighters in five villages north of Yambio (Bazumburu, Bazungua, Bodo, Gitikiri and Rimenze). Unspecified number of civilians killed in the fighting (10 spread over 4 locations), as well as houses burned down and property destroyed. At least 7,000 people were displaced from the area.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO attacked the Lolere police post west of Torit town, along the Torit-Juba road, leaving two fire brigade members killed.

SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; UN Security Council; International Crisis Group
NOTES: Battles between Lam Akol's National Democratic Movement and Agwelek forces in northern Manyo county over 3-4 January. NDM claims to have killed more than 25 Agwelek forces while Agwelek claims to have killed 37 NDM, including two generals.

ACTOR2: SSPPF: South Sudan Peoples Patriotic Front
SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; OCHA; UN Security Council
NOTES: Clashes between government troops and suspected SSPPF fighters in five villages north of Yambio (Bazumburu, Bazungua, Bodo, Gitikiri and Rimenze). Unspecified number of civilians killed in the fighting (10 spread over 4 locations), as well as houses burned down and property destroyed. At least 7,000 people were displaced from the area.
five people were killed in separate incidents of cattle raiding in Northern Liech State at the beginning and the middle of the week
Unidentified men have kidnapped a Christian religious leader from his home in South Sudan's capital Juba
Seven people were confirmed killed and others wounded in an attack by gunmen along the Juba-Yei road near Jebel Kenyi in Loka.
government forces intercepted armed men when they attacked government positions in Torit. No casualties reported.

SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; UN Security Council; International Crisis Group
NOTES: Battles between Lam Akol's National Democratic Movement and Agwelek forces in northern Manyo county over 3-4 January. NDM claims to have killed more than 25 Agwelek forces while Agwelek claims to have killed 37 NDM, including two generals.

SPLA arrested six MSF humanitarian workers while on duty (two foreigners and four South Sudanese), suspecting them of smuggling guns to the opposition in Yei. Two staff were released on 27 January and four ithers on 31 March.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO accuse government forces of attacking their base in Nasser town with tanks and helicopters. No people reportedly killed.

ACTOR1: SPLA/M-In Opposition-Deng Gai: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition (Deng Gai Faction)
ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Government claims that SPLA-IO forces loyal to vice president Taban Deng Gai captured a number of places in Upper Nile's new Latjoor state (Nordeng, Dhuoreding, Torpuot, Ketbek, Nyariew and Mandeng) from SPLM-IO forces led by Machar over 5-7 January. SPLA-IO forces denied the capture, except for Nordeng. Both sides said more than 40 of their opponents died during Jan. 5 fighting.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: South Sudanese rebels loyal to former First Vice President Riek Machar announced that they captured Morobo County in Yei River State. The rebels claimed to kill 'several' government soldiers. Government forces denied the claim. Fighting escalated in the area.

ACTOR1: SPLA/M-In Opposition-Deng Gai: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition (Deng Gai Faction)
ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Government claims that SPLA-IO forces loyal to vice president Taban Deng Gai captured a number of places in Upper Nile's new Latjoor state (Nordeng, Dhuoreding, Torpuot, Ketbek, Nyariew and Mandeng) from SPLM-IO forces led by Machar over 5-7 January. SPLA-IO forces denied the capture, except for Nordeng.

SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio; Radio Easter
NOTES: One person was killed and six others injured when a soldier opened fire on a funeral rite in Yei. On the same day, another two people were killed in the Kimbi area of Yei by an unknown gunman.

New party called the National Movement for Change (NMC) is formed from outside by the former governor of Western Equatoria. No mention if military campaign will be carried out or if will enter into agreement with active rebel groups of the country.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Five soldiers loyal to Lam Akol were captured during a battle by forces under the command of the SPLA-IO Sector One commander Lt. Gen. Johnson Olony at Kaka miliarity base

ACTOR1: SPLA/M-In Opposition-Deng Gai: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition (Deng Gai Faction)
ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Government claims that SPLA-IO forces loyal to vice president Taban Deng Gai captured a number of places in Upper Nile's new Latjoor state (Nordeng, Dhuoreding, Torpuot, Ketbek, Nyariew and Mandeng) from SPLM-IO forces led by Machar over 5-7 January. SPLA-IO forces denied the capture, except for Nordeng.
Unknown gunmen killed two people near Lokiliri county in Jubek state, as they were travelling from Magwi in Imatong State, to Juba.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: 250 government soldiers defected to the armed oppposition led by Riek Machar in Mayom county, Unity State, accusing the government of tribalism and nepotism.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Reported fighting between government and opposition near Yei town left 41 killed. Each side claimed victory and put the same number of fatalities on the other side.

SPLA soldiers detained and shot at a group of 10 Kakwa youths in Yei, killing four of them instantly and injuring four others. SPLA soldiers detained a doctor who treated the injured and accused him of providing medical treatment to rebels, prevented the medical evacuation of two of the injured and detained three carers travelling with the men. At least one of the injured men later died of his injuries.
Four people killed by suspected youth cattle raiders in Amolbut village, Lakes state, as they stole 60 heads of cattle and 30 goats from the area.

Suspected Murle tribesmen abducted a child at Tedo village in Pochalla North county. Around the same time, suspected Murle tribesmen also killed a member of Presbyterian Church near Kudbuudi village in Pochalla North county.
Murle tribesmen reportedly killed a local administrator in Neum village in Pochalla North county.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Clashes between SPLA and SPLA-IO in Unity in January left at least five civilians dead.
Unidentified gunmen abducted two children and wounded another in Bor East County.
Local officials in Buaw, Koch County, claimed that armed youth from Rubkona carried out cattle raids around between 16 December-1 March, resulting in civilian casualties.
At least 3 aid workers killed in January in South Sudan.
Intercommunal tensions in Rubkway, outside Leer, led to civilian casualties between 16 December-1 March.

SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; National Courier; Eye Radio; UN Security Council
NOTES: Clashes between herders and suspected Murle tribesmen after an attack on Paluoch cattle camp in Duk Padiet by the tribesmen. At least 12 civilians were killed, while another 13 were injured and 2,000 cattle were stolen.
Mathiang Anyoor militia, allied to the government, reportedly burned down at least 14 houses and the Catholic diocesan pastoral centre in Lutaya area, near Yei.

ACTOR1: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition-Deng Gai: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition (Deng Gai Faction)
SOURCE: Voice of America (Washington, DC); Sudan Tribune
NOTES: 11 SPLA-IO officials defected to Taban Deng Gai's faction to join the government's national dialogue.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Report that around 800 fighters from Lam Akol's National Democratic Movement defected to SPLA-IO led by Machar in Upper Nile early January. Lam Akol denied the report.
Clashes between local residents and suspected Murle tribesmen left at least two people killed and another wounded in Pentin village in Pochalla South County.
Government claims to have expulsed all remaining Sudanese SPLM-N rebels from Wau and Raja in Bahr el Ghazal out of the country in line with a 2012 cooperation deal between the two countries.
Residents living in displaced camps under UN protection in Juba demonstrated peacefully in support of Donald Trumps swearing-in as the 45th president of the United States.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO reportedly repulsed a government attack on their positions in Khor Natabu area along the Bringi-Wau road in Wau State. No mention of fatalities. Authorities denied the clash.

ACTOR1: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Road ambushed by men allegedly affiliated with a former SPLA coloner who had just defected to SPLA-IO left 2 SPLA soldiers killed and four injured near Mayom junction.

Suspected herders from Tonj state killed three civilians in or around Wath-lelo, Atido and Maleng areas of Jur River County between 20-21 January, after their cows were allegedly raided by rebels. Houses were burnt down and large populations displaced from the area.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; Radio Don Bosco; UN Security Council
NOTES: Clashes between local farmers and Tonj pastoralists south of Wau town left at least two dead. During clashes between the Tonj and Wau communal militias in January, Tonj pastoralists were reportedly supported by government forces, while farmers in Wau were aided by SPLA-IO.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-); SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio; Associated Press International; South Sudan Protection Cluster; UN Security Council
NOTES: Clashes between government and opposition forces at Mondikolok in Kajo-keji county over 22-23 January. On the first day of clashes, at least seven civilians were reportedly killed, including a catechist, and one woman was raped, forcing thousands of people to flee to Uganda for safety. Clashes continued the following day with an attack on Mere police station in Lire payam, resulting in another two casualties. The clashes occurred after the SPLA arrested several persons in the area accused of supporting SPLA-IO rebels.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio; Associated Press International; South Sudan Protection Cluster; UN Security Council
NOTES: Clashes between government and opposition forces at Mondikolok in Kajo-keji county over 22-23 January. On the first day of clashes, at least seven civilians were reportedly killed, including a catechist, and one woman was raped, forcing thousands of people to flee to Uganda for safety. Clashes continued the following day with an attack on Mere police station in Lire payam, resulting in another two casualties. The clashes occurred after the SPLA arrested several persons in the area accused of supporting SPLA-IO rebels.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO forces reportedly regain control of Nordeng area in Nasser after SPLA removed them from the area the week prior. No mention of fatalities.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
SOURCE: South Sudan News Agency (SSNA); Sudan Tribune
NOTES: SPLA-IO forces reportedly ambushed SPLA soldiers and supporting militias who were attacking and burning villages in Magwi county at Obbo Payam. At least 6 SPLA soldiers were killed. SPLA denied the claims.

ACTOR1: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
SOURCE: Sudan Tribune; Gurtong; UN Security Council
NOTES: A clash between cattle keepers and SPLA-IO left at least six people killed in Wau state between 16-27 January, including two local community inhabitants, and many houses burnt down. SPLA-IO was said to have supported Wau farmers in clashes with Tonj herders in January, while Tonj herders were reportedly aided by government forces.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
SOURCE: South Sudan News Agency (SSNA); Sudan Tribune; Radio Easter
NOTES: SPLA reportedly attacked SPLA-IO positions in and around Yei but were repulsed by SPLA-IO, leaving 18 killed. Civilians were reportedly killed in the fighting and displaced to border areas. In the course of the fighting, SPLA soldiers allegedly burnt down houses in Lutaya area, including a Pastoral Centre of the Catholic Diocese.

ACTOR1: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
ALLY_ACTOR_1: SSAF: South Sudan Armed Forces; FDP: Federal Democratic Party
ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition-Deng Gai: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition (Deng Gai Faction)
NOTES: A senior general loyal to former First Vice President Machar defected to the SPLA-IO faction allied to incumbent First Vice President Taban Deng Gai with 175 of his soldiers in Panyijiar County in Unity state. The day after, 11 military officers from the opposition Federal Democratic Party/ South Sudan Armed Forces (FDP/SSAF) also defected to the SPLM-IO under Taban Deng Gai, while beginning of February, one of the SPLA-IO officials in Canada also announced his defection to Daban Deng's faction.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio; Associated Press International; South Sudan Protection Cluster; UN Security Council
NOTES: Clashes between government and opposition forces at Mondikolok in Kajo-keji county over 22-23 January. On the first day of clashes, at least seven civilians were reportedly killed, including a catechist, and one woman was raped, forcing thousands of people to flee to Uganda for safety. Clashes continued the following day with an attack on Mere police station in Lire payam, resulting in another two casualties. The clashes occurred after the SPLA arrested several persons in the area accused of supporting SPLA-IO rebels.

ACTOR1: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO members killed a member of the Ceasefire and Transitional Security Arrangements Monitoring Mechanism (CTSAMM) after he left the UN camp in Hai Jazeera near Wau town. Four men working inside the UN camp were later arrested over allegedly coordinating the killing.

Alleged clashes between government forces and unknown gunmen in the week of 23 January after the gunmen ambushed a vehicle in Amaki along the Maridi-Rumbek road. No reported fatality. Authorities denied the claims.

SOURCE: Sudan Tribune; South Sudan News Agency (SSNA); UN Security Council
NOTES: Clashes between SPLA and rebels led by General Olonyi allied with Riek Machar in Detang, Lelo, Artakong and Burkiny areas near Malakal town, Upper Nile. The rebels reportedly repulsed government forces. At least five civilians were killed during the clashes.

ACTOR1: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Suspected SPLA-IO rebels attacked the Kajo Keji police station, leaving two police officers killed.

SOURCE: Sudan Tribune; South Sudan News Agency (SSNA); UN Security Council
NOTES: Clashes between SPLA and rebels led by General Olonyi allied with Riek Machar in Detang, Lelo, Artakong and Burkiny areas near Malakal town, Upper Nile. The rebels reportedly repulsed government forces. At least five civilians were killed during the clashes.

SOURCE: Sudan Tribune; South Sudan News Agency (SSNA); UN Security Council
NOTES: Clashes between SPLA and rebels led by General Olonyi allied with Riek Machar in Detang, Lelo, Artakong and Burkiny areas near Malakal town, Upper Nile. The rebels reportedly repulsed government forces. At least five civilians were killed during the clashes.
Clashes between herders and local farmers as a farmer sought to prevent the herders' cattle to enter his lands in Pochalla North county in Jonglei left two herders killed.
Suspected herders from Tonj state stormed a cattle camp at night in Aliny village near Wau town, leaving three children killed and another three wounded.
Heavy fighting reported between government and Agwelek forces in Doleib Hill of Upper Nile at a point between 25 and 28 January. No mentioned fatality.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: A number of new and unnamed armed groups have reportedly emerged in Upper Nile after having recently broken away from SPLA-IO led by Riek Machar. Ceasefire monitors underlined that it hampered their capacity to reach some parts of the country.

SOURCE: Sudan Tribune; Radio Tamazuj; MSF; UN Security Council
NOTES: Clashes between SPLA and SPLA-IO allied Agwelek forces in Owachi area in Upper Nile, near Malakal. One shell landed close to the MSF clinic in Malakal town.
Ambush by armed youth from Abiriu county on cattle raiders from Rumbek at Amolbut payam in Abiriu, Western Lake state, left two of the raiders dead.

Suspected herders from Tonj state killed at least 11 civilians and burnt down houses in or around Wath-lelo, Atido and Maleng areas of Jur River County. Thousands of people were displaced to Wau town as a result of the tensions.
Clashes between SPLA and SPLA-IO allied Agwelek forces in Lelo, Warjwok and Detang of Upper Nile. No mention of fatalities.
Clashes between SPLA and SPLA-IO allied Agwelek forces in Lelo, Warjwok and Detang of Upper Nile. No mention of fatalities.

Academic lecturers indefinitely suspended lessons at the University of Juba to protest the arrest and detention of two academics the day before for holding an alleged secret meeting after being suspended from the university for demanding the Vice Chancelor's removal in December.
Clashes between SPLA and SPLA-IO allied Agwelek forces in Lelo, Warjwok and Detang of Upper Nile. No mention of fatalities.
Shelling by South Sudanese air force on an IDP camp in Wau Shilluk area in Upper Nile left at least 5 civilians killed and 25 injured. Unconfirmed numbers of dead bodies in the bush.
Unidentified gunmen opened fire on Sudanese refugees at Adjuong Thok camp in Pariang in Unity, killing at least one of them.

SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; MSF; UN Security Council
NOTES: Clashes between SPLA and SPLA-IO allied Agwelek forces on the west bank of the Nile near Malakal. An IDP camp as well as the town's market in Wau Shilluk are hit by shelling and mortar fire during the fighting, forcing populations to flee. No fatality.
Gunmen opened fire on a car along the Juba-Nimule road, leaving at least three people killed and several others wounded.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Clashes between government and opposition forces in Kuek (melut county), Abu Khadra and Mamur areas of Renk, Upper Nile, around 30 January. In Kuek, SPLA-IO claimed that SPLA was supported by Sudanese rebels from JEM and SPLM-N. Significant displacement reported from the area, with some humanitarian organisations shutting down operations due to insecurity.

Unknown gunmen attacked two humanitarian convoys between 29-31 January in Bentiu, Unity state, raising concerns about the safety of humanitarian convoys that take advantage of the dry season to preposition stocks in remote regions.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Clashes between government and opposition forces in Gabat (Manyo county) and Khor (Melut county) areas of Upper Nile on 30 January. Opposition claimed to have captured the two areas, which SPLA denied. No reported fatalities.

Reports that Misseriya tribesmen have been attacking Dinka Malual farmers, fishermen and hunters over January-February in Aweil East, leaving at least four people killed in an attack on the farm of Yel Deng Nguel. Other ambushes have forced people to stop hunting and fishing in the area.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; SPLM-N: Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement (North)
ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune; IOM; UN OCHA
NOTES: Clashes between government and opposition forces in Kuek (melut county), Abu Khadra and Mamur areas of Renk, Upper Nile, around 30 January. In Kuek, SPLA-IO claimed that SPLA was supported by Sudanese rebels from JEM and SPLM-N. Significant displacement reported from the area, with some humanitarian organisations shutting down operations due to insecurity.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Clashes between government and opposition forces in Gabat (Manyo county) and Khor (Melut county) areas of Upper Nile on 30 January. Opposition claimed to have captured the two areas, which SPLA denied. No reported fatalities.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Clashes between government and suspected SPLA-IO forces in Wau town at night left at least three killed and two wounded.
SPLA allegedly attacked civilian houses in Yei town over 30-31 January, leaving at least three civilians killed, three others wounded and property looted.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Clashes between government and opposition forces continued from 31 January-1 February in Wadakona area in Upper Nile. Opposition fighters were allegedly repulsed by government forces. SPLA-IO denied the clashes in Wadakona. No reported fatality.
SPLA allegedly attacked civilian houses in Yei town over 30-31 January, leaving at least three civilians killed, three others wounded and property looted.
Unknown gunmen ambushed two people on the road in Bar Mayen county, Aweil state, around 1 February, leaving one of them killed. Police later arrested four in connection with the killing.
SPLA spokesman claims that SPLA bombarded SPLA-IO positions in Jonglei and Unity on the week of 27 January. No reported fatality.
SPLA spokesman claims that SPLA bombarded SPLA-IO positions in Jonglei and Unity on the week of 27 January. No reported fatality.

Between 22 January-21 February, following clashes in the Kajo-Keji area, extensive vandalism and looting of vacated houses, shops, church compounds, NGO compounds (notably the American Refugee Committee's) and of the hospital has been reportedly carried out by unknown assaillants, leaving the area deprived of basic services.

ACTOR1: Bor Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Dinka Bor cattle keepers, supported by SPLA, allegedly attacked armed opposition elements in Kajo Keji and Nyepo counties end January/early February. No reported fatality.

Toposa militiamen allegedly supported by SPLA forces attacked settlements of Kenyan pastoralists who had crossed the border from Turkana in search of water and pasture for their cattle, forcing them back to Turkana. No reported fatality.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Clashes between government and opposition forces in Mustagbal and Abu Shar areas of Upper Nile, near Malakal. No reported fatality.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO accused Egyptian air force of dropping six bombs in Wau Shilluk in Upper Nile. SPLA denied any support by Egyptian forces.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Clashes between government and opposition forces continued from 31 January-1 February in Wadakona area in Upper Nile. Opposition fighters were allegedly repulsed by government forces. SPLA-IO denied the clashes in Wadakona. No reported fatality.

ALLY_ACTOR_2: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Presidential Security Unit
NOTES: Unknown gunmen shot and killed a Presidential Guard soldier and driver for President Kiir's wife while he was off duty in Wau town. Police later arrested two over the attack.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO accused Egyptian air force of dropping six bombs in Wau Shilluk in Upper Nile. SPLA denied any support by Egyptian forces.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; SPLM-N: Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement (North)
ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO claimed that government forces, supported by Sudanese rebels from the SPLM-N and JEM, attacked their positions in Mustaqbal, Gabat near Wadakona and Dentoang on 2 February. Many fatalities reported. SPLA denied receiving support from Sudanese rebels. SPLA-IO claimed to have captured nine government soldiers and destroyed four military vehicles.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
SOURCE: South Sudan News Agency (SSNA); Xinhua General News Service; Associated Press International; Sudan Tribune
NOTES: An SPLA Colonel defects to SPLA-IO denouncing institutionalized tribalism, fascism and political militarism. A week later, one of the most senior SPLA Generals from Equatoria resigned denouncing ethnic bias and "unacceptable cycles of violence" in the country, while SPLA announced that about 151 SPLA-IO rebels defected from Akobo in Jonglei.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; SPLM-N: Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement (North)
ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO claimed that government forces, supported by Sudanese rebels from the SPLM-N and JEM, attacked their positions in Mustaqbal, Gabat near Wadakona and Dentoang on 2 February. Many fatalities reported. SPLA denied receiving support from Sudanese rebels. SPLA-IO claimed to have captured nine government soldiers and destroyed four military vehicles.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; SPLM-N: Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement (North)
ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO claimed that government forces, supported by Sudanese rebels from the SPLM-N and JEM, attacked their positions in Mustaqbal, Gabat near Wadakona and Dentoang on 2 February. Many fatalities reported. SPLA denied receiving support from Sudanese rebels. SPLA-IO claimed to have captured nine government soldiers and destroyed four military vehicles.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; SPLM-N: Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement (North)
ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO claimed that government forces, supported by Sudanese rebels from the SPLM-N and JEM, attacked their positions in Dentoang for the second day. Government forces were repulsed.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO accused Egyptian air force of dropping more than nine bombs in rebel-held territories around Kaka in Upper Nile. SPLA denied any support by Egyptian forces.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Clashes reported between government and opposition forces in Gabat near Wadakona on 3 February. Government forces were repulsed.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Renewed clashes between government and opposition forces in Wau Shilluk, Upper Nile. The town was reportedly deserted.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Clashes reported between opposition forces and the "Mathiang Anyoor militia" of Bahr el Ghazal, loyal to the government, at Ombasi in Yei River County, left 32 government militiamen killed.
Suspected Murle militiamen ambushed a group of four women in Baidit in Jonglei's Bor South, leaving two killed and the two others injured.

SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; Xinhua General News Service
NOTES: Clashes between government forces and Agwelek militia allied with SPLA-IO in Upper Nile's Kuek (Melut county) over 5-6 February. Government forces claimed to have regained the area from the rebels, which SPLA-IO denied.

SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; Xinhua General News Service
NOTES: Clashes between government forces and Agwelek militia allied with SPLA-IO in Upper Nile's Kuek (Melut county) over 5-6 February. Government forces claimed to have regained the area from the rebels, which SPLA-IO denied.
Unknown gunmen described as "rebels" reportedly fired mortar rounds on Torit town. No casualties.
Suspected Murle militiamen ambushed a group of women collecting firewood at Panwell in Jonglei's Bor South, leaving two killed and others injured.

SOURCE: Xinhua General News Service; Radio Tamazuj
NOTES: Clashes between government forces and Agwelek militia allied with SPLA-IO in Upper Nile's Detang over 7-9 February. Government forces claimed to have regained this areas from the rebels.

The Ngop River County Commissioner's bodyguard allegedly shot and killed a pastoralist youth leader in Eastern Lakes state as ordered by the Commissionner over unclear circumstances. Clashes erupted the following day.

Clashes between government forces and Agwelek militia allied with SPLA-IO in Upper Nile's Wau Shilluk over 7-9 February. Government forces claimed to have regained this area from the rebels. SPLA-IO claims Egyptian air force also bombed their positions on 9 January.
Unknown gunmen shot and killed a prison warder off duty at his home in Yambio. Police later arrested six in connection with the attack.
Clashes between government forces and Agwelek militia allied with SPLA-IO in Upper Nile's Detang over 7-9 February. Government forces claimed to have regained this areas from the rebels.
Suspected cattle raiders from Boma allegedly attacked a cattle camp in Duk County of Jonglei. No casualty.

ACTOR1: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Suspected SPLA-IO reportedly attacked civilians in Kaya area of Morobo county, leaving at least five pastoralists and 80 heads of cows killed.
Report that SPLA burnt down more than 75 civilian houses at Doro, Buagyi and Lanyi respectively in Western Equatoria around 8 February, and looted food items and cattle. Residents fled in fear.
A trader was killed in Lui town in Mundri. Some accused SPLA. SPLA denounced as dangerous propaganda.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; SPLM-N: Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement (North)
SOURCE: South Sudan News Agency (SSNA); UNMISS; Radio Tamazuj; UN Security Council
NOTES: Government soldiers backed by Sudanese rebels (from SPLM-N and JEM) attacked Agwelek forces' positions at Owachi near Malakal but were repulsed by the rebels. "Significant" casualties reported by UN on both sides - SPLA-IO claiming to have killed more than 98 government soldiers, while SPLA denied the clashes.
Clashes between government forces and Agwelek forces allied with SPLA-IO in Tonga, Panyinkang county. "Significant" casualties on reported on both sides.

Clashes between government forces and Agwelek militia allied with SPLA-IO in Upper Nile's Wau Shilluk over 7-9 February. Government forces claimed to have regained this area from the rebels. SPLA-IO claims Egyptian air force also bombed their positions on 9 January.
Clashes between youth pastoralists and soldiers in Mapuordit payam in Yirol west county, Lakes state following the killing of one of their leaders, left two people killed.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of Egypt (2014-); JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; SPLM-N: Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement (North)
ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO claims government forces backed by Sudanese rebels (from SPLM-N and JEM) attacked their positions in Warjuok, Owachi and Wau Shilluk on 9 February, and were repulsed. At least five SPLA-IO soldiers were killed and 36 injured; some fatalities also reported on the government's side (10 spread across the 3 locations). The government claimed to have regained Wau Shilluk on 9 February after 3 days of clashes against Agwelek forces. In Wau Shilluk and Owachi, SPLA-IO also claimed Egyptian air force bombed their positions on 9 February.
Clashes between government forces and Agwelek militia allied with SPLA-IO in Upper Nile's Detang over 7-9 February. Government forces claimed to have regained this areas from the rebels.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO claims Egyptian air force bombed their positions in Doleib Hill and Jonglei Canal of Upper Nile. No reported fatality.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO reportedly ambushed government forces who had just been dispatched to protect pastoralists in Kaya area of Morobo after recent violence targeting them. No mentioned fatality.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of Egypt (2014-); JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; SPLM-N: Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement (North)
ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; South Sudan News Agency (SSNA)
NOTES: SPLA-IO claims government forces backed by Sudanese rebels (from SPLM-N and JEM) attacked their positions in Warjuok, Owachi and Wau Shilluk on 9 February, and were repulsed. At least five SPLA-IO soldiers were killed and 36 injured; some fatalities also reported on the government's side (10 spread across the 3 locations). The government claimed to have regained Wau Shilluk on 9 February after 3 days of clashes against Agwelek forces. In Wau Shilluk and Owachi, SPLA-IO also claimed Egyptian air force bombed their positions on 9 February.

One of the bodyguards of the Imatong State Governor shot at SPLA soldiers stationed near the Governor's residence, and SPLA soldiers returned fire, leaving at least one killed and three injured. The clashes followed a presidential decree removing the Imatong Governor from his position.

SPLA soldiers shot and killed a civilian in Torit when he failed to obey orders to stop due to "low hearing capacity. This follows a presidential decree removing the Imatong Governor from his position and ensuing clashes between his bodyguards and the soldiers, whom later deployed heavily in the area.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of Egypt (2014-); JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; SPLM-N: Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement (North)
ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; South Sudan News Agency (SSNA); Xinhua General News Service
NOTES: SPLA-IO claims government forces backed by Sudanese rebels (from SPLM-N and JEM) attacked their positions in Warjuok, Owachi and Wau Shilluk on 9 February, and were repulsed. At least five SPLA-IO soldiers were killed and 36 injured; some fatalities also reported on the government's side (10 spread across the 3 locations). The government claimed to have regained Wau Shilluk on 9 February after 3 days of clashes against Agwelek forces. In Wau Shilluk and Owachi, SPLA-IO also claimed Egyptian air force bombed their positions on 9 February.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: JEM: Justice and Equality Movement; SPLM-N: Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement (North)
ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO claims government forces backed by Sudanese rebels (from SPLM-N and JEM) attacked their positions in Wunkur Payam of Panyikang County and were repulsed.
Unknown gunmen shot and killed a UN staff member while returning back to his residence in Torit from a funeral in the early hours of 10 February.
Mortar attack on Wau Shilluk in the early morning of 10 February. No reported fatality. A CTSAMM team was prevented from accessing the area as a result.

SOURCE: Sudan Tribune; Radio Tamazuj; Catholic Radio Network; Eye Radio; UN Security Council
NOTES: Suspected SPLA soldiers from the Nesitu military outpost attacked Kubi village in Eastern Equatoria, along the Juba-Nimule highway, detaining and torturing 48 young men (all whom were later released except for four), beating and raping an unconfirmed number of women and girls, and looting the village. Residents fled the town, leaving only 15 elderly. Three of the four suspects were arrested three weeks later.
Unknown gunmen attacked a military truck at Mondikolok village in Kajo-keji County, leaving an SPLA soldier killed and several others injured.

A trader from Boma state was killed and five others injured (including one among the assaillants) in an attack by unidentified gunmen on traders involved in buying and selling of cattle at Magri area in Mangalla County. One suspect was later arrested in connection with the attack.
Clashes between SPLA and Agwelek forces in Owach area of Upper Nile. Reports that SPLA succeeded in gaining control of the area - though SPLA-IO denied the claims. No mentioned fatality.

SOURCE: Sudan Tribune; Radio Tamazuj; Catholic Radio Network; Eye Radio
NOTES: Suspected SPLA soldiers from the Nesitu military outpost attacked Kubi village in Eastern Equatoria over two days, along the Juba-Nimule highway, detaining and torturing 46 young men (42 whom were later released as four remained missing), beating and raping at least six women and girls, and looting the village. Residents fled the town, leaving only 15 elderly. Three of the four suspects were arrested three weeks later.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA attacked SPLA-IO forces in Ambasa area near Yei, but were reportedly repulsed. No mentioned fatality.
Unknown gunmen attacked a group of local youth along the Wau-Roc Roc Dong road in Jur River area, leaving at least three people killed and two others injured.
Members of the White Army (loyal to SPLA-IO) defected to SPLA, leaving the group's headquarters in Yuai to join the army in Patuet, near Pajut, in Jonglei.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO ambushed government forces in along the Tigitigi-Yei road, leaving "many" SPLA soldiers killed and at least two rebel soldiers injured.
Local officials in Buaw, Koch County, claimed that armed youth from Rubkona carried out cattle raids around between 16 December-1 March, resulting in civilian casualties.
Three women were raped in Juba and another three sexual harassed by unknown assaillants in February.

Clashes between suspected Tonj pastoralists and local farmers left nine people dead on both sides in Jur River County in February. Three suspects as well as two chiefs and another man from Tonj accused of inciting violence were arrested early March.
Intercommunal tensions in Rubkway, outside Leer, led to civilian casualties between 16 December-1 March.

Clashes between White Army (loyal to SPLA-IO) and defectors from the White Army who had just joined the SPLA in Patuet near Pajut in Jonglei. SPLA supported the defectors in the clashes and followed the White Army to their headquarters in Yuai (Uror county), where they dislodged them. No reported fatality.
Armed men ambushed an SPLA vehicle and a cattle truck between Tangjon and Black Rock along the Pibor-Gumuruk road mid-February.
Armed men ambushed a vehicle at Kavagoch village along the Pibor-Gumuruk road mid-February, leaving two civilians killed and five wounded.
Gunmen attacked a cattle camp in Turalei county, Twic state, leaving at least two herders killed, another injured and cattle stolen. SPLA later recovered the cattle.

Clashes between White Army (loyal to SPLA-IO) and defectors from the White Army who had just joined the SPLA in Patuet near Pajut in Jonglei. SPLA supported the defectors in the clashes and followed the White Army to their headquarters in Yuai (Uror county), where they dislodged them. No reported fatality.
White Army (loyal to SPLA-IO) attacks government forces at Yuai to try to re-capture the area. No reported fatality. Civilians and aid staff fled from the town.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
SOURCE: Sudan Tribune; Radio Tamazuj; Agence France Presse -- English
NOTES: Five senior government and military officials resigned between 17-20 February criticising the government's failure to implement the August 2015 deal and accusing it of crimes, corruption and ethnic bias, including the Minister of labour and public services and his Deputy, the SPLA Director of military justice, the Head of the military Court and a Brigadier General in charge of logistics. The former declared his allegiance to SPLA-IO leader Riek Machar.

Unknown assaillants tortured and shot dead a local artist on the road to Tiindoka on the outskirst of Yambio. Two girls were arrested in connection with the killing. The man was a former member of the South Sudan National Liberation Movement.
A former state governor split from the ruling SPLM to form a new political entity named the Republican Party of South Sudan.

Unknown gunmen attacked a commercial vehicle carrying 14 passengers at Bilinyang area along the Juba-Mangala road, leaving four killed and robbing the others of their belongings. SPLA later arrested five in connection with the event.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Clashes between government and opposition forces in Kulothok village of Canal county in Jonglei. After the clashes, government forces allegedly arrested a group of 31 civilians (27 women, three youths and an infant), locked them inside a cattle shelter and set fire to it. Only one of them managed to escape, while the others were burnt alive. SPLA-IO said at least 37 were burnt alive. SPLA denied the claims, saying the area was under rebel control.

Clashes between government and opposition forces in Kulothok village of Canal county in Jonglei. After the clashes, government forces allegedly arrested a group of 31 civilians (27 women, three youths and an infant), locked them inside a cattle shelter and set fire to it. Only one of them managed to escape, while the others were burnt alive. SPLA-IO said at least 37 were burnt alive. SPLA denied the claims, saying the area was under rebel control.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO reportedly attacked government positions at Bumuri village in Kajo-keji county. Government troops repulsed the rebels. No reported fatality.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Clashes between government and opposition forces in Liwolo payam of Kajo-Keji in the week of 20 February, 20km away from the largest IDP site, Logo, causing fear of more violence spreading to Kajo-Keji town.
Unidentified gunmen set fire to homes in various neighborhoods of Yei town, leaving several houses destroyed. No casualty.
